articles.headline: Trump Authorizes Tariffs, Defying Allies at Home and Abroad
articles.snippet: The president raises levies on foreign steel and aluminum in hopes of reviving fading domestic industries. But imports from Mexico and Canada will be spared for now.
articles.abstract: The president raises levies on foreign steel and aluminum in hopes of reviving fading domestic industries. But imports from Mexico and Canada will be spared for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump defied opposition from his own party and protests from overseas as he signed orders on Thursday imposing stiff and sweeping new tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. But he sought to soften the impact on the United States’ closest allies with a more flexible plan than originally envisioned.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: It’s True: False News Spreads Faster and Wider. And Humans Are to Blame.
articles.snippet: False claims posted on Twitter were 70 percent more likely to be shared than the truth, researchers at M.I.T. found. And people appear to prefer false news.
articles.abstract: False claims posted on Twitter were 70 percent more likely to be shared than the truth, researchers at M.I.T. found. And people appear to prefer false news.
articles.lead_paragraph: What if the scourge of false news on the internet is not the result of Russian operatives or partisan zealots or computer-controlled bots? What if the main problem is us?

articles.headline: Japan Wants More Women in Construction. Pink Toilets May Not Be Helping.
articles.snippet: The industry is scrambling to deal with a labor shortage, but some say a tone-deaf government recruiting effort can’t overcome serious workplace issues.
articles.abstract: The industry is scrambling to deal with a labor shortage, but some say a tone-deaf government recruiting effort can’t overcome serious workplace issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Getting hired seemed like the tough part.

articles.headline: Russia’s Greatest Problem in Syria: Its Ally, President Assad
articles.snippet: The Syrian leader’s push for a military victory has put the Kremlin in a corner, unable either to risk a withdrawal or to craft the political settlement that would cement its gains in the region.
articles.abstract: The Syrian leader’s push for a military victory has put the Kremlin in a corner, unable either to risk a withdrawal or to craft the political settlement that would cement its gains in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Sitting down with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria late last year, a senior Kremlin envoy described the benefits to come as Moscow shepherded the Syrian conflict toward a political settlement, particularly in rebuilding the war-ravaged country.

articles.headline: What History Has to Say About the ‘Winners’ in Trade Wars
articles.snippet: Has President Trump studied the Smoot-Hawley act of 1930? Or the McKinley tariff act of 1890? Maybe he should.
articles.abstract: Has President Trump studied the Smoot-Hawley act of 1930? Or the McKinley tariff act of 1890? Maybe he should.
articles.lead_paragraph: With President Trump ordering steep new tariffs on imported steel and aluminum on Thursday, and with America’s trading partners threatening to retaliate, it looks as if Mr. Trump will get the trade war that he seems to want and that he thinks will be “easy” for the United States to win.

articles.headline: North Korea Asks for Direct Nuclear Talks, and Trump Agrees
articles.snippet: No sitting American president has ever met a North Korean leader, and the meeting would be a breathtaking gamble for Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: No sitting American president has ever met a North Korean leader, and the meeting would be a breathtaking gamble for Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, has invited President Trump to meet for negotiations over its nuclear program, an audacious diplomatic overture that would bring together two strong-willed, idiosyncratic leaders who have traded threats of war.

articles.headline: Why G.O.P. Is Spending Millions on a Soon-to-Vanish Seat in Trump Country
articles.snippet: If the Democrats win a special House race in Pennsylvania’s 18th District, the alarm bells will be audible across the country.
articles.abstract: If the Democrats win a special House race in Pennsylvania’s 18th District, the alarm bells will be audible across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Never has so much money been spent so quickly on a political race with so little real meaning than on the House special election here, but to Republicans, the public relations debacle that would come with a loss this Tuesday is a price they cannot bear.

articles.headline: Merck C.E.O. Ken Frazier on Death Row Cases and the Corporate Soul
articles.snippet: Corner Office, a regular interview with leading C.E.O.s, returns. In the first installment, Ken Frazier talks about race, justice and his break with President Trump.
articles.abstract: Corner Office, a regular interview with leading C.E.O.s, returns. In the first installment, Ken Frazier talks about race, justice and his break with President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: The role of the chief executive has never been more complex — or more consequential.

articles.headline: A Quiet Exodus: Why Black Worshipers Are Leaving White Evangelical Churches
articles.snippet: Megachurches around the country were trying to racially integrate and finding some success. Then came the 2016 election.
articles.abstract: Megachurches around the country were trying to racially integrate and finding some success. Then came the 2016 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Charmaine Pruitt wrote the names of 12 churches on a sheet of paper, tore the paper into 12 strips, and dropped them into a Ziploc bag. It was Sunday morning and time to pick which church to attend.

articles.headline: How Would U.S. Verify That North Korea Is Disarming?
articles.snippet: North Korea has tested six nuclear weapons and, according to American intelligence agencies, has 20 to 60 more.
articles.abstract: North Korea has tested six nuclear weapons and, according to American intelligence agencies, has 20 to 60 more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 18 years ago, one of North Korea’s most senior military officers stepped into the Oval Office and handed President Bill Clinton a letter from the isolated nation’s leader, inviting him to Pyongyang.

articles.headline: How Much Is Martin Shkreli’s One-of-a-Kind Wu-Tang Album Worth?
articles.snippet: The disgraced former pharmaceuticals executive reportedly bought the sole copy of “Once Upon a Time in Shaolin” for $2 million. Now, one memorabilia dealer said, “the bloom is off the rose.”
articles.abstract: The disgraced former pharmaceuticals executive reportedly bought the sole copy of “Once Upon a Time in Shaolin” for $2 million. Now, one memorabilia dealer said, “the bloom is off the rose.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli, the disgraced former pharmaceuticals executive, was sentenced to seven years in prison for securities fraud in Brooklyn on Friday, and a judge has ruled that the government will have its pick of his assets to satisfy the $7.36 million judgment against him.
